Note:
This list includes versions beginning, ‘First…’ formerly listed separately as 799; see also 553, 976, 4810, 4840; Ringler Jr. (1992)
XRingler Jr., William A. Bibliography and Index of English Verse in Manuscript 1501-1558. London: Mansell, 1992; prepared and completed by Michael Rudick and Susan J. Ringler TM 170; Ringler Jr. (1988)
XRingler Jr., William A. Bibliography and Index of English Verse Printed 1476-1558. London: Mansell, 1988TP 160.5.
_description: Precepts in -ly; the texts show much variation — 16 lines in most witnesses, monorhyming

OxfBal354.Transcription:
Aryse erlyserve God devoutly þe world besiliGo thi way
                    sadlyanswere demvrelyGo to thy mete appetently& arise
                    temperatly& to þi soper soberly& to thy bede
                    merylyAnd be ther jocondly & slepe suerly
OxfBal354.Facsimiles:
Early Manuscripts at Oxford University: Facsimile
                    of Oxford, Balliol MS 354.
         (http://image.ox.ac.uk/show?collection=balliol&manuscript=ms354).
OxfBal354.Editions:
Flügel,  Ewald. 
             “Liedersammlungen des XVI Jahrhunderts….” 
             Anglia
         26 (1903): 94-285: 172.
Dyboski,  R.,
                        ed.  
             Songs, Carols and Other Miscellaneous Poems from Balliol MS. 354,
                Richard Hill’s Commonplace Book.
EETS
          e.s. 101 (1908); repr. 1984: 139.

CamMagPep1047.First Lines:
A ryse erly and serue god devoutlyAnd the worlde
                    besyly…
CamMagPep1047.Last Lines:
…And then slepe suverly [sic]This ffesyk is
                    holi
CamMagPep1047.Attributed Title: A medsyn for the stomake (f. 1) in rubric

         Adelaide: Mary Martin Books, [1970?]; Cambridge, 1972.

BLIB49408.First Lines:
Aryse erlyserue god deuotly& the worlde besylydo
                    þi woork a vysely…
BLIB49408.Last Lines: …Please thi love duly& she slep suerly
BLIB49408.Note:
Added by hand to blank leaf: 16 lines, written as prose; possibly copied
                    from 
            Boke of Hawking, Hunting, and Blasing of Arms, [St Albans, 1486]  since same hand copies other prose texts from this
                    print on 34v-35 (Four things that make a man wise; ‘Who that
                    makyth in cristmas a dogge to his larder’; etc.).
BLIB49408.Editions:
Bühler,  Kurt. 
             “Middle English Apophthegms in a Caxton Volume: Libri impressi cum notis
                manuscriptis X.” 
             English Language Notes
         1 (1963-64): 81-4: 82.

TCD516.First Lines:
Aryse erlyeserue god devoutleThe worlde heselydo þi
                    warkes wysle…
TCD516.Note:
14 monorhyming lines written as prose, added to originally blank space
                    in lower margin of page by hand of of the fifteenth century.
